docs.lead_paragraph: Every so often during a national convention, a politician says something that shines right through the accumulated oratory hanging like fog above the convention floor, creating an image that requires deeper contemplation. Though hardly known for his speaking skills, former Senator Bill Bradley did just that the other night when he told the Democratic convention that if all the 13.5 million poor children in America were gathered in one place, they would form a city bigger than New York -- and ''we would then see child poverty as the slow-motion national disaster that it is.'' This Dickensian vision was a wonderfully descriptive way of saying that while Americans can sympathize with individual cases of poverty, and ''would never turn their backs on a starving child,'' it is next to impossible for them to imagine the totality of the problem. Put all these children in one place in the mind's eye, and the reality becomes inescapable.

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK ALBANY: FIRE CLOSES BUILDINGS Two state office buildings were evacuated yesterday after an electrical fire filled them with smoke. Nine hundred people working for various state agencies have offices in the two 23-story towers across from the Capitol, but it is unclear how many were in the building. Peter Constantakes, a spokesman for the Office of General Services, said the fire started around 2 p.m. in the basement of one tower, as workers carried out routine maintenance on electric cables. He said three people were treated at Albany Medical Center for minor injuries. No time was given for the buildings to reopen. Richard Perez-Pena (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: Karenna Gore Schiff, the candidate's daughter, tonight filled the role once played by governors, senators, former presidents and former first ladies by seconding her father's nomination to be president, praising him in remarks for balancing family and government work, and helping her with a dinosaur diorama after a long day of Congressional hearings. In their unending quest to make national conventions into sunny talk shows they hope the networks will broadcast, the parties have banned internal party argument over policy, serialized roll calls over three nights and miniaturized important speeches (except by President Clinton).

docs.lead_paragraph: The way Wayne Chang saw it, it was one thing to go to a Chinese medicine clinic for acupuncture or herbal treatments, quite another for a medical procedure. ''I would go to a straight-up American doctor for Western medicine,'' Mr. Chang, a Flushing resident, said as he stared down the block at the New York Beijing Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine, a clinic that investigators shut down on Tuesday after charging its staff with practicing unlicensed medicine. ''But a lot of people around here don't care. It's cheap.''

docs.lead_paragraph: The stage does not look like the Capitol, but there have been more senators, representatives and Congressional candidates speaking at the Democratic National Convention than can be found on the floor of either chamber most of the time. With the convention half over, 40 present and perhaps future lawmakers have spoken about everything from campaign finance legislation to the environment to the minimum wage to health insurance -- tracking the issues Vice President Al Gore is campaigning on -- and hoping to win back control of the narrowly Republican House, and maybe even the Senate.

docs.lead_paragraph: WAINEWRIGHT THE POISONER By Andrew Motion Illustrated. 276 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $26. Thomas Griffiths Wainewright was a minor English painter of the first half of the 19th century who was convicted of forgery and transported to Australia, where he did hard labor for seven years. He was an unusual criminal in that he knew people like Samuel Taylor Coleridge, William Blake and Lord Byron, and when his term of hard labor was finished, he gained recognition in Tasmania as a portrait painter. He was called ''an insufferable fop'' by one person who knew him, ''a daring and impudent braggart'' by another. Most important as background to Andrew Motion's unusual biography of Wainewright, he probably murdered his uncle, his mother-in-law and his sister-in-law, though he was never convicted of those crimes.

docs.lead_paragraph: It might be a stretch to say that Washington Democrats are paying rapt attention to next month's primary for United States senator, in which the state insurance commissioner, Deborah Senn, and former United States Representative Maria Cantwell, now a wealthy Internet executive promoting her experience in the ''new economy,'' are battling for the right to take on the three-term Republican incumbent, Slade Gorton. Indeed, even as Ms. Senn arrived here the other evening for a campaign speech to an electricians' union that had already endorsed her, several of the electricians said they could not name the candidates in the Sept. 19 primary, and they also labored a bit to identify the issues they considered most pressing in the contest.

headline.main: Democrats Hopeful in a Washington Race
